text:
SPEAKER 1: Was it
difficult to get

permits to operate a business
in Soweto at that time?
PETER VUNDLA: Yeah.
Oh.

Everything at the time was about
permits, it was about passes.

And ours was a very
regimented society.

You had to get a pass for
this, a permit for this,

a certificate for this,
and that kind of thing.

And those were some
of the impediments

that stood in the way
of black business,

and which, in fact, rendered
it almost impossible

to do any business
because we're not
supposed to be business people.
The thing was so geared--

I really-- I think you need
to understand that Soweto
was more of a labor camp.

It wasn't going to
be an area where
there's economic activity and--

except, we were placed in
Soweto to provide labor

to white people in
the Northern suburbs,

in Johannesburg, in the
cities and, largely,

through what they call the
Group Areas Act, where,

during apartheid, there was
separate-- what they call

separate development, but
there wasn't much development
on the black side. (CHUCKLING)

SPEAKER 1: It was separate
but it wasn't developed.
PETER VUNDLA: Not equal, yes.
Yeah.

So, black townships were
never geared for any kind
of economic activity.

And most times,
black people would

shop in the white--
so-called white areas

and go back with their
goods, back to the townships.

So, what little
business there was then,

that's what black
business people
captured in those black areas.
